Is psychTestR right for me?

Source: vignettes/a-right-for-me.Rmd
a-right-for-me.Rmd

The modern psychologist has access to many different software packages for developing and administering psychological tests. Each of these packages is better suited to certain use cases than others. For example, if the test is just a simple one-off questionnaire, straightforward tools such as Survey Monkey and Google Forms may well be sufficient. If the test depends on specialist lab hardware and requires highly accurate response time measurement, then one might use PsychoPy, a powerful cross-platform package written in Python. The Javascript package jsPsych is a strong alternative to PsychoPy that is targeted instead at web data collection. If the test depends heavily on modern psychometric techniques, such as item response theory and adaptive testing, the R-based framework Concerto may be preferable. If the test requires many online participants to interact in complex networks, the Dallinger framework is arguably the best option. These are just a few of the many packages available for psychological testing.

A primary focus of psychTestR is modularisation. psychTestR is well-suited for developing modular psychological tests (e.g. IQ tests, memory tests, personality questionnaires) that can be easily distributed as R packages, chained together into long test batteries, and deployed online. In contrast, most other tools are optimised for implementing individual experiments. We think that psychTestR is a great option if you want to create an experimental paradigm or individual-differences measure that can easily be reused by other scientists and easily incorporated into larger experiments.

A second focus of psychTestR is internationalisation. We developed psychTestR in tandem with the LongGold project, a longitudinal study of musical abilities, intelligence, self-concepts, and personality that collects data from many schoolchildren in different countries. A key priority was to facilitate the construction of tests that support multiple languages that can be switched between with minimum effort. psychTestR is a great option if you wish to construct psychological tests that generalise well to different languages.

A third focus of psychTestR is powerful server-side computation. psychTestR is written in the programming language R, and each participant session interacts continuously with an R server to guide the participant’s progress through the experient. This is in contrast to client-side frameworks such as jsPsych, where the majority of the processing happens in the participant’s web browser. As a result, psychTestR can take advantage of the full set of free software packages on the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN), including many advanced statistical packages such as catR and brms. This is particularly useful for implementing complex stimulus selection procedures such as IRT-based adaptive testing. It also makes psychTestR a natural option for psychology researchers whose primary programming language is R.

A fourth focus of psychTestR is exposing the power of Shiny. Shiny is a powerful web framework for developing interactive web apps, heavily supported by RStudio and used by many thousands of developers. By exposing Shiny’s tools for creating interactive widgets and programmatically generating HTML, psychTestR makes it easy to construct customised experiment interfaces without having to learn HTML or Javascript. However, Shiny is a server-side framework, and hence does not contribute much to experiments that need precise timing of visual stimuli and response recording, which generally require client-side programming. For such applications it is best to rely more on Javascript frameworks such as jsPsych, which can themselves be embedded within psychTestR.

Still interested? Continue with An introduction to psychTestR !

Developed by Peter M. C. Harrison.
